headline: Asian shares advance, yen slips after AI stocks push higher on Wall Street
summary: Shares surged higher Monday in Asia and U.S. futures rose after a rebound in AI-related stocks like Nvidia spurred a rally on Wall Street.  Tokyo's Nikkei 225 gained 1.9% to 50,455.07, helped by hefty gains for computer chip makers and other companies benefiting from the boom for artificial intelligence.  Semiconductor maker Tokyo Electron jumped 6.7% while chip testing equipment maker Advantest gained 4.7%.

content.title: Asian shares advance, yen slips after AI stocks push higher on Wall Street
content.summary: Shares surged higher Monday in Asia and U.S. futures rose after a rebound in AI-related stocks like Nvidia spurred a rally on Wall Street.  Tokyo's Nikkei 225 gained 1.9% to 50,455.07, helped by hefty gains for computer chip makers and other companies benefiting from the boom for artificial intelligence.  Semiconductor maker Tokyo Electron jumped 6.7% while chip testing equipment maker Advantest gained 4.7%.

headline: World shares are mixed and Japan's yen slips after AI stocks push higher on Wall Street

In Asian trading, Tokyo's Nikkei 225 gained 1.8% to 50,402.39, helped by hefty gains for computer chip makers and other companies benefiting from the boom for artificial intelligence.

headline: Chinese Chipmakers Race to IPO After Back-to-Back Listings Surge
summary: The surge in listings is coming on the back of two blockbuster trading debuts that signaled insatiable demand for future national champions that analysts say could one day even rival the likes of Nvidia Corp. While some of these firms are already domestic industry leaders, they remain an obscurity to many international investors, making their share sales in Hong Kong a crucial test of confidence.  Earlier this month, AI chipmaker Moore Threads Technology Co. saw its stock jump 425% on the first day of trading in Shanghai, followed by the 693% gain for MetaX Integrated Circuits Shanghai Co.’s listing.

content.title: Chinese Chipmakers Race to IPO After Back-to-Back Listings Surge
content.summary: The surge in listings is coming on the back of two blockbuster trading debuts that signaled insatiable demand for future national champions that analysts say could one day even rival the likes of Nvidia Corp. While some of these firms are already domestic industry leaders, they remain an obscurity to many international investors, making their share sales in Hong Kong a crucial test of confidence.  Earlier this month, AI chipmaker Moore Threads Technology Co. saw its stock jump 425% on the first day of trading in Shanghai, followed by the 693% gain for MetaX Integrated Circuits Shanghai Co.’s listing.

headline: Exclusive-Nvidia aims to begin H200 chip shipments to China by mid-February, sources say
summary: Nvidia has told Chinese clients it aims to start shipping its second-most powerful AI chips to China before the Lunar New Year holiday in mid-February, three people ​familiar with the matter told Reuters.  The U.S. chipmaker plans to fulfil initial orders from existing ‌stock, with shipments expected to total 5,000 to 10,000 chip modules - equivalent to about 40,000 to 80,000 H200 AI chips, the first ‌and second sources said.  Nvidia has also told Chinese clients that it plans to add new production capacity for the chips, with orders for that capacity opening in the second quarter of 2026, the third source said.

content.title: Exclusive-Nvidia aims to begin H200 chip shipments to China by mid-February, sources say
content.summary: Nvidia has told Chinese clients it aims to start shipping its second-most powerful AI chips to China before the Lunar New Year holiday in mid-February, three people ​familiar with the matter told Reuters.  The U.S. chipmaker plans to fulfil initial orders from existing ‌stock, with shipments expected to total 5,000 to 10,000 chip modules - equivalent to about 40,000 to 80,000 H200 AI chips, the first ‌and second sources said.  Nvidia has also told Chinese clients that it plans to add new production capacity for the chips, with orders for that capacity opening in the second quarter of 2026, the third source said.

headline: SoftBank races to fulfill $22.5 billion funding deal with OpenAI, sources
summary:
STORY: SoftBank Group is reportedly racing to close a $22.5 billion funding commitment to OpenAI by the end of the year.

According to sources, it's through an array of cash-raising schemes, including a sale of some investments.

They added it could tap its undrawn margin loans borrowed against its valuable ownership in chip firm Arm Holdings.

The bet on OpenAI is among the biggest yet by SoftBank CEO Masayoshi Son.

The Japanese billionaire wants to improve his firm's position in the race for artificial intelligence.

To come up with the money, Son has already sold SoftBank's entire $5.8 billion stake in AI chip leader Nvidia.

As well as offloading $4.8 billion of its T-Mobile stake, and slashing staff.

Son has slowed other dealmaking at SoftBank's Vision Fund to a crawl.

And two of the sources speaking to Reuters said any deal above $50 million now requires his explicit approval.

SoftBank's push to marshal funds offers a window into the strain faced even by the world's biggest dealmakers.

They're scrambling to finance ambitious AI data center projects worth hundreds of billions of dollars.

SoftBank declined to comment.

It secured a deal to invest in OpenAI at a $300 billion valuation in April.

Since then, the valuation of OpenAI has risen dramatically.

And the company is in talks to raise additional funding from investors, including Amazon.

content.title: SoftBank races to fulfill $22.5 billion funding deal with OpenAI, sources
content.summary:
STORY: SoftBank Group is reportedly racing to close a $22.5 billion funding commitment to OpenAI by the end of the year.

According to sources, it's through an array of cash-raising schemes, including a sale of some investments.

They added it could tap its undrawn margin loans borrowed against its valuable ownership in chip firm Arm Holdings.

The bet on OpenAI is among the biggest yet by SoftBank CEO Masayoshi Son.

The Japanese billionaire wants to improve his firm's position in the race for artificial intelligence.

To come up with the money, Son has already sold SoftBank's entire $5.8 billion stake in AI chip leader Nvidia.

As well as offloading $4.8 billion of its T-Mobile stake, and slashing staff.

Son has slowed other dealmaking at SoftBank's Vision Fund to a crawl.

And two of the sources speaking to Reuters said any deal above $50 million now requires his explicit approval.

SoftBank's push to marshal funds offers a window into the strain faced even by the world's biggest dealmakers.

They're scrambling to finance ambitious AI data center projects worth hundreds of billions of dollars.

SoftBank declined to comment.

It secured a deal to invest in OpenAI at a $300 billion valuation in April.

Since then, the valuation of OpenAI has risen dramatically.

And the company is in talks to raise additional funding from investors, including Amazon.

headline: Sharon AI Completes US$100m Convertible Note Capital Raising
summary: NEW YORK, December 22, 2025--SharonAI Holdings Inc. and its subsidiaries ("Sharon AI"), Australia’s leading Neocloud (SHAZ:OTC Markets, SHAZW:OTC Markets), announces the completion of an at least US$100m capital raising in the form of a Convertible Note, as of the close of business on Friday, the 19th of December, 2025. Both new and existing institutional investors and strategic corporates participated, with Canaccord Genuity Australia appointed as the sole lead manager.

headline: Nvidia Gains, Hospitals Hurt: Congress Winners and Losers
summary: The legislative branch’s acquiescence to Donald Trump’s sharp tariff increases raised input costs across the economy and provoked retaliatory moves against US farm exports.  The health-care sector, renewable energy companies and Las Vegas’s casinos have taken legislative hits while chipmakers, drug companies and private equity fended off potentially costly congressional interventions.  Chief Executive Officer Jensen Huang’s visits to Congress and the White House also helped pave the way for Trump administration actions easing export restrictions so the company could sell advanced chips to Chinese customers.

content.title: Nvidia Gains, Hospitals Hurt: Congress Winners and Losers
content.summary: The legislative branch’s acquiescence to Donald Trump’s sharp tariff increases raised input costs across the economy and provoked retaliatory moves against US farm exports.  The health-care sector, renewable energy companies and Las Vegas’s casinos have taken legislative hits while chipmakers, drug companies and private equity fended off potentially costly congressional interventions.  Chief Executive Officer Jensen Huang’s visits to Congress and the White House also helped pave the way for Trump administration actions easing export restrictions so the company could sell advanced chips to Chinese customers.
